Award.AwardTitle: Building Computational Thinkers through Informal Exhibit Experiences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The Museum of Science in Boston will investigate different museum exhibit design strategies for building computational thinking capacity among diverse middle and high school learners. The goal of this project is to identify how novice learners can be supported to make sense of and interact with computational thinking tools, problem solving strategies, and technical solutions. Exhibits designed in this project will support visitors to engage with the steps of algorithmic problem solving and to evaluate the efficiency and correctness of algorithms. Each of the exhibits involved in this project will undergo initial design and development, including formative prototyping and evaluation to ensure they are easily usable and meet intended educational goals. This traveling museum exhibition has the potential not only to stimulate awareness and practice of computational thinking skills, but also to stimulate capacity, interest, and self-efficacy for computing and computing careers among diverse learners who may not otherwise have exposure to computational thinking.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Building Computational Thinkers Project Outcomes report 

Building Computational Thinkers explored how educators and designers can most effectively support the development of computational thinking capacity as a part of museum exhibits, and how these learning experiences can be customized to meet the needs of learners from diverse backgrounds. This study focused on The Science Behind Pixar (Pixar), a 13,000 square foot travelling exhibition about the computer science, mathematics, and science behind Pixar?s innovative films, and specifically looked at the affordances of three exhibit design approaches for conveying problem decomposition content, including:

  • Multimedia narratives that used storytelling and direct instruction strategies through videos to describe specific examples of how Pixar filmmakers used computational thinking to solve creative challenges. Visitors heard from an expert about how a complex problem was broken down into pieces that could be processed by a computer. Essential elements of these videos included an authentic story, personal connections, and a cohesive explanation of the problem and solution.
  • Solution explorations that let visitors explore, through interactive exhibits, the ways that Pixar filmmakers decompose creative challenges into discrete, computable functions. Visitors toggled functions on and off within the overall algorithm and adjusted the parameters of functions to learn how experts broke down problems and then built them back up from their functional elements in order to solve them. These exhibits provided guided exploration to the user, and had well-defined tasks to accomplish.
  • Creative design activities that were constructionist-based, interactive experiences that engaged visitors in evaluating and refining a set of parameters. Visitors were able to design their own creative solution to a complex problem by modifying the fundamental elements of an algorithm. These exhibits placed a greater emphasis on exploration and on users defining their own goals.  

Phase 1 of this research study aimed to understand how novice learners could be helped to understand and interact with computational thinking tools, problem solving strategies, and technical solutions to address complex, creative challenges. This research identified areas in which novices and experts differed in their approach to problem decomposition exhibits leading to the creation of specific support strategies that brought novice thinking closer in sophistication to expert thinking and problem-solving description. The strategies generated through the research findings included: 1) Authentic context and process that helped novices to recognize how an activity relates to programming, as well as increase their feelings of agency and identity about this type of work; 2) Authentic language related to programming was added to encourage novices to associate the exhibits? content or task with programming or math; and 3) Opening the black box revealed the underlying mechanisms of an exhibit?s program without overwhelming novices.

Phase 2 of the research study explored the outcomes of engaging middle and high school youth in each of the three different types of problem decomposition exhibits. It focused on investigating the abilities of the three design strategies, which included the scaffolds described above, to build the capacity, feelings of efficacy, and interest in computational thinking of novice learners. Our research found that using a combination of the computational thinking exhibits positively impacted youths? perceptions and beliefs around programming, and their understandings about what computer programming entails. Additionally, two of the exhibit design approaches worked particularly well for girls. We found that solution explorations, which guide an individual through an expert?s solution to complex problem, is especially good at heightening the interest of girls in computational thinking. Multimedia narratives, which share how a complex problem can be broken down into functional parts, can be particularly effective for helping girls to increase their understandings of problem decomposition.

The Science Behind Pixar opened at the Museum of Science, Boston in June 2015, resulting in the highest summer attendance at the Museum of Science in 17 years. Two copies of this exhibition are traveling both nationally and internationally through 2027. The exhibition, including these exhibits, is expected to be viewed by at least 3 million visitors in total. Additionally, The Science Behind Pixar website showcases and shares resources from the research project. It also includes articles written as part of this research that outline outcomes about computational thinking in Pixar exhibition. Since the launch of Pixar website (sciencebehindpixar.org) in 2017, the site has received 164,304 page views. A total of 114,010 of these views took place between December 2017 and today.
